none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, January 24, 1881
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from J. T. Hand, January 24, 1881
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 8 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
Brenham Texas.
Jan 24th 1881.

My Dear Professor -
"Procrastination is the
thief of time" - Your good letter reached
me by due course of mail -
Have been waiting for something to
"turn up" & it has - I mean our "great
good Governor" has sent in his message -
Well it is unique - sui generis et al -
I read most of it - in sections - but there
were more sections than I have had
spare time. The venerable Gov. exhibits
reminds one of more than the Self Complacency
Self-Sufficiency & Self-laudation of Mississippis
great Senator: "It is I fellow citizens it is I"
He slaps Uncle Sam in the face and
proclaims himself the Moses who
has lead us out of the wilderness -
The mountains clap their hands & shout
for joy - "The rocks & the rills" - Think we
blush? He feels that it is "good to be here"
Poor Coke & Hubbard Ought to read

**Analysis of a Letter from 1881**

Alright, let's break this down. It's addressed to a "Professor," and seems to be dated January 24th, 1881, from Brenham, Texas.  The handwriting is...well, it's a bit of a challenge, but I'm ready for it.  The first lines dive right in with a quote about procrastination, and then some commentary on a recent "message" from the current Texas Governor.  It appears the writer is being quite critical.

I've got the image of the letter and the initial impression is the writer isn't impressed by the Governor's speech.  He uses words like "unique" and "sui generis," and it sounds like he read this message with a certain amount of sarcasm. There's a lot of name-dropping; he's comparing this governor to a "great Senator" from Mississippi, and even invokes the image of Moses leading folks out of the wilderness...which I can interpret is a mocking comment.

The writer also seems to be making a sly comparison to previous Texas governors, Richard Coke and Richard B. Hubbard.  He seems to be hinting that they would have something to say about this governor's self-laudatory style. I have spent time looking at what the last word is.  Given the context and the visual clues, I'm going with "read", but the handwriting at the end is a little odd, so it's a qualified interpretation.

[Header] [1881, Jan. 24]

Crookedness upon Texas, by their inefficient
administrations! Thanks to our stars -
we are out of the wilderness! -
The election for Senator, I presume will
take place tomorrow - You need not be
surprised if we lose our Gov -
If he fail of the Senatorship - you surmise
correctly of future movements - looking
to the law Dept of a State University -
Republics ought not to be "ungrateful" -

Well we have not had more than 1/2 doz
sunny days in 5 months - The weather
has received too much gratuitous abuse
I forbear - I beg to state it has been
cold wet & muddy - I wish you
had run by to see us on your late
trip down the Central - as you
had several days longer recess
than you anticipated -

I am now rather inclined to go in to
the sheep business - How is your
stock interest turning out?
Stock or lumber promises better than teaching.

**Transcription Analysis and Interpretation**

Alright, let's get down to it. I've got this handwritten document in front of me, and my task is to provide the most accurate transcription possible. It's a letter, written on lined paper. The ink is faded, and I'd guess it's graphite or a light ink. The date in pencil at the top right, `[1881, Jan. 24]`, is interesting – looks like an annotation, but part of the content. The handwriting is cursive and a bit hurried, which adds to the fun! Some words are faint, but let's dive in.

First, the `[Header] [1881, Jan. 24]` is an archival annotation. The letter begins. I'm going line by line.

*   **Line 1:** "Crookedness upon Texas, by their inefficient". Okay, the first word is the key. Is it "Crookedness" or something else? After some consideration, I'm confident it's "Crookedness". "Texas" is perfectly clear, and the phrase "inefficient administrations" makes "Crookedness" fit well. No, "Crookedness" feels most correct, and the capital "T" in "Texas" is a great reference point.
*   **Line 2:** "administrations! Thanks to our stars -". "Administrations" makes perfect sense, continuing from the previous line. And "Thanks to our stars" is crystal clear. Exclamation mark.
*   **Line 3:** "we are out of the wilderness! -". I've got "wilderness" here, no doubt.
*   **Line 4:** "The election for Senator, I presume will". "The election" and "for Senator" are straightforward.
*   **Line 5:** "take place tomorrow - You need not be". "Take place tomorrow" is clear.
*   **Line 6:** "surprised if we lose our Gov -". We're reading this as "Governor", and the dash makes sense here.
*   **Line 7:** "If he fail of the Senatorship - you surmise". The word is "fail". Clear. "Senatorship" is also clear.
*   **Line 8:** "correctly of future movements - looking". "Correctly of future" all check out.
*   **Line 9:** "to the law Dept of a State University -". Ah, the abbreviation. It looks like "Dept". The context is clear, so "Department" is the intended meaning. "University" is easily readable.
*   **Line 10:** "Republics ought not to be "ungrateful" -". The word "ungrateful" is in quotes.
*   **Line 11:** "Well we have not had more than 1/2 doz". "1/2 doz" looks perfect and fits.
*   **Line 12:** "Sunny days in 5 months - The weather". It seems to be the number "5".
*   **Line 13:** "has received too much gratuitous abuse". All straightforward here.
*   **Line 14:** "& forbear - I beg to state it has been". Now, this is where it gets interesting! At first glance, that symbol looks like an ampersand, or possibly "I forbear", given the style of "I". It looks as though it could mean "I will stop complaining, but I must say...". "I forbear" seems the most likely, and grammatically, this transition makes sense, meaning, "I am going to stop talking about the weather".
*   **Line 15:** "cold wet & muddy - I wish you". The letter has "cold" then a scribbled word, then "& muddy". The word in the middle is probably "wet". With the context, and how it is written, it seems to be "wet".
*   **Line 16:** "had run by to see us on your late". No issues here.
*   **Line 17:** "trip down the Central - as you". I'm making a note here - "Central" probably refers to a railroad.
*   **Line 18:** "had several days longer recess". "Recess" is perfect.
*   **Line 19:** "than you anticipated -". Complete.
*   **Line 20:** "I am now rather inclined to go in to". This is clear.
*   **Line 21:** "the sheep business - How is your". "Sheep business" is clear.
*   **Line 22:** "stock interest turning out?". The question mark is key.
*   **Line

[1881, Jan. 24]

I saw a gentleman from Bryan
last week - He reports the outlook rather
gloomy for Bryan as a business point -
I trust you are doing well -
Many matters I would like to talk
with you about - that it is not
profitable or prudent to write -
Deo volente we will meet next Summer
Please see Dick Humphrey & collect $50
for me - I am now sure he is playing
the rascal & intends to dodge the
matter - The claim is for a Chicken
house - worth twice that sum - & due
more than a year ago - I dislike to
trouble you with this matter - but I
need the money & it is long past due -
All well except Mrs. H who is suffering
from cold & Neuralgia -
Your letters are always welcome - & read
with interest -

Your friend
J. T. Hand

**Transcription of a Handwritten Letter**

Alright, let's break this down. First, there's a date at the top, seemingly added later and enclosed in brackets: `[1881, Jan. 24]`. I need to start with that for accuracy.

Now, into the letter itself, it seems like the writer's just catching up. He saw a gentleman from Bryan last week, and the news isn't great, business-wise. He hopes I'm doing well. He mentions there are matters he wants to discuss in person, but not in a letter.

He's hoping we can meet next summer, "Deo volente," of course, meaning "God willing."

Then, here's a request, "Please see Dick Humphrey & collect $50". Now, about that $50, it looks a bit messy in the original, but it's most likely $50 based on the notation, given the mention of a "chicken house worth twice that sum." $5 or $500 is very different. If $5, it's a minor debt. The writer believes that the person owing is "playing the rascal" and avoiding payment. The claim is for a "Chicken" house "worth twice that sum," which is past due for over a year. He dislikes bothering me with it, but he needs the money.

Everyone is well, except Mrs. H, who's suffering from a cold and neuralgia. That's a common Victorian complaint.

He ends by saying my letters are always welcome and read with interest.

The signature is J. T. Hand. Seems like the writer is J. T. Hand. The writing style has a good flow, which I'll preserve. The line breaks are intentional, so I'll be sure to transcribe it line by line. I will be careful in my transcription, to reproduce what is presented.
